abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is modest; Bank performance
            is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is unsatisfactory.
            Among the lessons cited were the following: 1) Complex
            project design should be avoided in a weak implementation
            environment. 2) Project objectives and components with TA
            requirements must be clearly aligned. 3) Borrower's
            high ownership and clear leadership are essential to ensure
            progress on significant policy and institutional reform. 4)
            Line of authorities for project management should be clearly
            defined. 5) The independent "Engineer" role should
            be separated from the "Employer" in a complex
            project with weak borrower implementation capacity. That is,
            for agencies with weak contract administration capacity, it
            is important to strongly insist on moving the
            "Engineer" role to an international (definitely
            not local) consulting firm. 6) Clear incentives or penalty
            mechanisms must be enhanced for better consultancy
            services.7) The maximum number of consultant firms forming a
            joint venture must be capped. 8) Wider civil society
            consultation, parallel implementation of social mitigation
            measures and higher quality impact assessment studies are
            essential for potentially controversial measures, such as
            non-motorized transport-free conversion. 9) Car parking
            strategy should be prepared for converted non-motorized
            transport -free streets. 10) Public relations and
            comprehensive communication strategy are particularly
            important for urban transport projects.

442551.trustfund:
TF035512-BANGLADESH - DHAKA URBAN
            TRANSPORT PROJECT,TF033363-BANGLADESH - DHAKA URBAN TRANSPORT,TF029464-PHRD-DHAKA URBAN TRANSPORT PROJ.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Dhaka Urban Transport Project
            - environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Dhaka Urban Transport Project will
            improve transport infrastructure, and services in the
            city's metropolitan area, including road improvement,
            traffic management, and construction of terminals. During
            the construction phase, major environmental impacts include
            air, and noise pollution, and, traffic disruption. Soil
            contamination is expected to rise during construction, and
            sludge discharges will occur. Mitigating measures include:
            regulation of roadsides, and systems to control oil
            spillage, as well as dissipation structures, and settlement
            basins to control drainage, and erosion. The Air Pollution
            Advisory Committee of stakeholders, will establish action
            plans, to control vehicular gas emissions, regulate testing
            in academic laboratories, and ensure effectiveness of air
            control programs, in addition to public awareness campaigns,
            and training. Noise barriers will be established at
            congested locations, and trees/shrubs will be planted as a
            practical effect to reduce traffic noise nuisances. Surface
            and groundwater pollution control, include the provision of
            dustbins, and the establishment of waste disposal locations.
            Legislative requirements should address the protection of
            flood zones, and those where discharges may disturb the
            quality of surface, or ground water. Project design would
            avoid sensitive areas to prevent adversity on flora, and
            fauna, and in open spaces and parks.

437852.trustfund:
TF035512-BANGLADESH - DHAKA URBAN
            TRANSPORT PROJECT,TF033363-BANGLADESH - DHAKA URBAN TRANSPORT,TF029464-PHRD-DHAKA URBAN TRANSPORT PROJ.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Dhaka Urban Transport Project's
            overall objectives are: a) to improve urban transport
            infrastructure and services in the Dhaka Metropolitan Area
            (DMA), and b) to strengthen institutional and policy
            framework and address long-term transport planning and
            coordination issues in the DMA. The project consists of five
            components. 1) Infrastructure development will include
            traffic management measures and system improvements, road
            improvements, rehabilitation of existing bus terminals,
            pedestrian facilities improvements, non-motorized transport
            network improvements, grade-separated interchange
            facilities, feasibility studies for flyover schemes at
            Mohahkali and Jatrabari, and flood damage rehabilitation of
            roads and drainage. 2) Equipment support will provide
            responsible agencies with necessary equipment, computers,
            accessories, and vehicles. 3) Institutional strengthening
            and capacity building will strengthen traffic management,
            project supervision and management, financial management,
            environmental management, and performance monitoring to
            implementing agencies through training, consultant services,
            and equipment. 4) Policy support and future studies will
            support the preparation of a long-term transport strategic
            plan. 5) Land acquisition and resettlement will prepare a
            policy framework for addressing negative impacts, and a
            Resettlement Action Plan to assist affected people.

            : resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
Civil works under the Dhaka Urban
            Transport Project will require relatively minor demolition,
            and/or removal of structures on public lands, but the need
            for resettlement, however minor, needs to be addressed. This
            resettlement action plan aims to minimize involuntary
            resettlement, through viable alternative project design
            options, and, where displacement is unavoidable, vulnerable
            groups will be assisted in order to, at minimum, regain
            their standard of living, at no cost to themselves. Despite
            the fact that project works will be implemented within the
            right of way, many squatter, and vendor encroachers will
            have to be displaced. While squatters, and vendor
            encroachers are not entitled to legal compensation, the
            project will support targeted populations to maintain their
            livelihoods, through assistance in replacing structures, and
            assets lost. Project affected populations will receive
            compensation for land losses, at an inclusive fifty percent
            land premium, or the value of equivalent replacement land.
            Losses of usufruct rights through mortgage, or leased
            property, will be compensated at twenty five percent of one
            year's net income, while, income losses from business
            activity, will be compensated based on current average
            annual net income, pro-rated for sixty days. However,
            considerable uncertainty on the compensation budget exist,
            thus, flexible budgetary planning will be required.
